    <title>Apple invests $1 billion in Chinese transportation service Didi Chuxing</title>
    <content type="html">  
  <img alt="" src="https://cdn0.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/ytqqgphGMHG7Xfn61j5ARKuIXn4=/2x0:1015x675/1310x873/cdn0.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/49585469/AppleEvent_1164.0.0.jpg" />



  <p>Apple has invested $1 billion into Didi Chuxing, a major Chinese ride-hailing service. Among other things, the move is intended to help Apple better understand China, its second-largest market after the US.</p>
<p>"We are making the investment for a number of strategic reasons, including a chance to learn more about certain segments of the China market," Apple CEO Tim Cook <a href="http://www.cnbc.com/2016/05/12/reuters-america-apple-invests-1-bln-in-chinese-ride-hailing-service-didi-chuxing.html">tells Reuters</a>. "Of course, we believe it will deliver a strong return for our invested capital over time as well." Cook also sees potential avenues for collaboration between the two companies.</p>

    <title>Mark Zuckerberg says there's 'no evidence' that Facebook staff suppressed conservative stories</title>
    <content type="html">  
  <img alt="" src="https://cdn0.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/DqpoT-CehlziycX3IJG-tI_8OJ4=/2x0:1016x676/1310x873/cdn0.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/49585265/mark-zuckerberg-theverge-stock-9_1020.0.jpg" />



  <p>Mark Zuckerberg has issued a statement in response to the <a href="http://www.theverge.com/2016/5/12/11665298/facebook-trending-news-topics-human-editors-bias">controversy</a> alleging that Facebook staff intentionally prevented stories with a conservative viewpoint from appearing in the site's Trending Topics section.</p>
<p>"We take this report very seriously and are conducting a full investigation to ensure our teams upheld the integrity of this product," Zuckerberg <a href="https://www.facebook.com/zuck/posts/10102830259184701">writes on Facebook</a>. "We have found no evidence that this report is true. If we find anything against our principles, you have my commitment that we will take additional steps to address it."</p>
<p>Zuckerberg says he will invite "leading conservatives and people from across the political spectrum" to discuss the matter in the coming weeks, with the aim of having a "direct conversation...</p>

    <title>UPS now lets you track packages for real — on an actual map</title>
    <content type="html">  
  <img alt="" src="https://cdn0.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/CSZ3uSoc0FXxTduzisinTndGrL4=/0x0:1024x683/1310x873/cdn0.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/49584903/2012-03-23_13-13-35-1024.0.jpg" />



  <p>There will be no more sweating in anticipation when your package shows as "out for delivery," my friends. UPS has finally rolled out <i>true</i> package tracking, letting you see exactly where the truck carrying your item is on a map right from your smartphone or PC.</p>
<p>Now don't get too excited just yet; for now, the minute-by-minute tracking — branded "Follow My Delivery" — is only available for pricey UPS Air and UPS Worldwide Express deliveries. And you'll need to sign up for a (free) UPS My Choice account if you want the advanced tracking capabilities. My Choice also lets you reroute "most" packages to your workplace, a neighbor’s house, or a nearby UPS Access Point location if you won't be home to sign for a precious delivery.</p>

    <title>Google will pay Arizona drivers $20 per hour to test self-driving cars</title>
    <content type="html">  
  <img alt="" src="https://cdn2.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/B9iB5vf5H7KEG7y6uWrv4UteY3o=/0x0:4816x3211/1310x873/cdn0.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/49584845/Kirkland_Self_Driving_Lexus_Press_2.0.0.jpg" />



  <p>Do you live in Arizona and want to get paid to "drive" a self-driving car? Google could have a job for you. The company is <a href="https://www.hireart.com/jobs/cd40b8f8/apply">looking for local drivers</a> to act as "vehicle safety specialists" who will be behind the wheel, ready to take over at a moment's notice, as the company expands its self-driving car fleet to Chandler, Arizona.</p>
<p>Employees will receive $20 per hour and work under 12-24 month contracts driving vehicles from six to eight hours per day, while providing "concise written and oral feedback to the engineering team." Drivers are required to have a bachelor's degree, a clean driving record and criminal history, and the ability to type at least 40 words per minute. They will also be expected to keep their work confidential and...</p>

    <title>Researchers made a drone that can land on walls like an insect</title>
    <content type="html">  
  <img alt="" src="https://cdn2.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/WuZgKZfWu5wdsyr6X9PMq4jiqH8=/0x0:1227x818/1310x873/cdn0.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/49584487/d.0.0.png" />



  <p>Researchers at Stanford are trying to give drones another of insects' useful traits: the ability to land on vertical walls, and even upside down. They've already gotten pretty far on a system that lets drones do that. As one of the researchers <a style="background-color: #ffffff;" href="http://spectrum.ieee.org/automaton/robotics/drones/microspines-make-it-easy-for-drones-to-perch-on-walls-and-ceilings">writes at IEEE Spectrum</a>, the setup has two parts: a rigid tail, and a pair of "microspines." The tail allows the drone to correctly position itself while landing; the two microspines, which are really just small textured pads, are then dragged along the wall, where they catch on microscopic grooves in the surface.</p>
<p>An earlier version of the tech was <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/16/science/robot-part-drone-part-gecko.html">shown this time last year</a>, but a new video demonstrates the researchers' progress. They have it set up on a modified commercial drone and are able to...</p>

    <title>Disney's telepresence robot is shockingly precise</title>
    <content type="html">  
  <img alt="" src="https://cdn3.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/Wmyg1KgYFjpkiMIrLhDkal-d_44=/0x0:1835x1223/1310x873/cdn0.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/49583663/Screen_Shot_2016-05-12_at_3.50.15_PM.0.0.png" />



  <p>Disney Research has built an incredibly accurate telepresence robot that can nearly match a human's motions one for one. The telepresence robot uses a combination of stereo cameras and an air and water hydraulics system, which allows for more precise controls by its human operator.</p>
<p></p>
<p>The operator uses a head-mounted display to see through the robots perspective, and can handle delicate objects like eggs without cracking them, and even thread a needle. Although this is far from the first telepresence robot — theme parks have used different variations of telepresence robots to allow characters to naturally interact with people — Disney's offering shows the potential of telepresence robots can go much farther than simply waving at kids in...</p>

    <title>These are the 1,000 websites Facebook watches for Trending Topics</title>
    <content type="html">  
  <img alt="" src="https://cdn0.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/ID5_0VQEDavk-klTB2BzNrR49vM=/0x0:2039x1359/1310x873/cdn0.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/49583863/facebook-stock-1101.0.0.jpg" />



  <p><a href="http://newsroom.fb.com/news/2016/05/information-about-trending-topics/">In a post today</a>, Facebook VP Justin Osofsky revealed more detail than ever before about the company's Trending Topics product, which faced <a href="http://gizmodo.com/former-facebook-workers-we-routinely-suppressed-conser-1775461006">accusations of liberal bias from a former employee</a> earlier this week. In the post, Osofsky detailed how potential topics are surfaced by an algorithm before being curated by editors, an explanation consistent with a leaked employee manual <a href="http://www.theverge.com/2016/5/12/11665298/facebook-trending-news-topics-human-editors-bias">published earlier today by <em>The Guardian</em></a>.</p>
<p>Along with new details on the company's process, Osofsky published <a href="https://fbnewsroomus.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/media1k-domains.pdf">a list of the one thousand websites Facebook watches for trending news</a>. The list includes a number of conservative outlets singled out by the former employee as targets of discrimination, including <em>Breitbart</em> and <em>The Washington Examiner</em>. <em>The Weekly Standard</em> and...</p>

    <title>Tap Strap wearable keyboard uses gestures to type on any surface</title>

  <img alt="" src="https://cdn3.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/GXoN8OkvmWT_DO71ieTg3ipya4c=/13x67:713x534/1310x873/cdn0.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/49583343/tapstrap.0.png" />



  <p>You can't accept a new kind of computer into your heart if you don't have a good way to input text. Hardly anyone picked up a smartphone until BlackBerry solved the thumb keyboard, and <em>still</em> most people didn't pick up smartphones until Apple solved the touchscreen keyboard. Some devices, like Google Glass and Apple Watch, have an opportunity to be a new kind of computer, but without an obvious way to type on them, they seem awkward and unnecessary.</p>
<p>My own personal favorite wearable computing pioneer, Thad Starner, is famously proficient at <a href="http://twiddler.tekgear.com/">one-handed typing with the Twiddler</a>. It lets him take notes unobtrusively, or pull up references while talking to people. There have been many other<a href="http://www.onehandedkeyboard.com/"> one-handed keyboards attempted</a>, but most of them...</p>

    <title>With its new keyboard, Google has colonized every major function of my iPhone</title>
    <content type="html">  
  <img alt="" src="https://cdn1.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/RN_CGKHbS2nKikOfTNreJiuZj5U=/0x713:750x1213/1310x873/cdn0.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/49583227/IMG_8143.0.0.PNG" />



  <p>I downloaded the new <a target="new" href="http://www.theverge.com/2016/5/12/11662616/google-gboard-keyboard-iphone-ios">Gboard for iOS</a> today, and have been really enjoying it so far. Along with wondering about what Google will tell advertisers now that they can read every single thing I type, I came to the realization that pretty much every major function of my iPhone has now been taken over by Google software.</p>
<p>I use Google products for email, search, photos, maps, and video. Gboard effectively puts Google inside every app I use that requires me to type, from texting to taking notes. The only activity that isn't really mediated by the search giant at this point are voice calls, although in the past I have used Google Voice.</p>
<p>This isn't an op-ed about how Apple is dying or how Google products are superior to others. Just an...</p>
